title: Cheatsheet
text: Cheatsheet

title: Hello World
text:
Hello World
The below python code takes the phrase “Hello World!” and prints it to the console. It’s a good way to check you are set up correctly!






This is using the in-build function called print(), which will output anything that we put inside the brackets.
Now try the below variations. Which ones work? Which don’t work? When one doesn’t work, what error message do you get? Why?

print(Hello World!)
print('Hello',  'World!')
print(55)
print(Fifty five)
print('Fifty five')
print('Fifty five
print(55.5)

Also try:

Can you use double quotes " " instead of single quotes? ' '
Can you combine double and single quotes "Like this'
Can you print this exactly (with the quotes): I "love" Python.
What happens if you put a # before print

title: Variables
text:
Variables
Variables are containers for storing data values. We can then use it elsewhere in our program without having to manually type it in again which can be really handy.
Try:






This is the same as our first example, but first we stored the information in a variable called x. We then told python to print whatever x is.
Next, try:






Did you get the output you expected?
Next, try:






What is different in this example? How does that change the output?

title: Careers
text: Careers

title: Set up
text:
We are going to use Python for this course. You can do this on campus from a University Computer, online using a free Google Colab account that you can access from any web browser, or by downloading Python and Visual Studio Code onto your own device.
Click below to see the set up instructions for each:

University ComputerOnline CloudOwn Device


To get set up, follow the below steps. Click each step for detailed instructions.






Step 1: Launch Visual Studio Code from AppsAnywhere






Type in AppsAnywhere to the windows bar. This will open in a web browser
Open the following two applications by typing the name in and clicking launch:

Python
Visual Studio Code





GIF of Opening VSCode











Step 2: Navigate to your OneDrive folder






Click “Open Folder” on the loading screen
Find your OneDrive folder. You should be able to recognise the files and folders listed, from what you have saved here in your other classes.
Create a new folder for this python course, and open this folder.




GIF of Opening OneDrive folder











Step 3: Install the python extension






Click the extensions tab
Search and install python




GIF of Making a Folder











Step 4: Create and run a Python file





You’re now ready to run some Python code!

Go back to your folder
Click the “New file” button
Give your file a name ending .py (e.g. “Test.py” )
Add the following line to your file


print("Hello World")


Press the run button

And that’s it - you’re all set up!



GIF of making a python File








Warning





Make sure you can find your file in file explorer. Always back up your work such as saving in OneDrive or emailing to yourself so that you don’t lose your progress.








Google Colab is a free tool for running python on a browser - from a file saved in your Google Drive.






Caution





You shouldn’t need a paid account for this course. If your work becomes too large, then I suggest downloading and running Python and Visual Studio Code on your device.



To get set up, follow the instructions below:






Set up Google Colab notebook






Sign into Google with any Google account
Go to Google Colab
Click file -> New Notebook in Drive
Name your file (e.g “Test.ipynb”) The file is an Ipython Notebook so ends with .ipynb instead of .py
Add and run the following code:


print("Hello World")




GIF of creating a Google Colab notebook





And that’s it for setting up with Google Colab!


If you’re working on your own laptop or computer it’s also possible to download and run Python and Visual Studio Code. These are both free, open-source programs.






Note





If you’re working on a tablet, chromebook or your device is typically slow, I recommend looking at the Google Colab option instead



Installing Python and VSCode can be a bit fiddley - let the teaching team know if you’d like any support.
Why two programs? Python is the programming language, that takes our data and does our analyses. Visual Studio Code is a program we use to edit and run our python files. It’s a text editor that is specialised for coding projects.






Step 1: Install Python





You can Install Python from this website. It should automatically detect whether you are on a Windows or a Mac PC and suggest which version to download. Click download and then follow the installation instructions.



Screenshot of Python website











Step 2: Install Visual Studio Code





Once Python is installed, you can install Visual Studio Code from this website.
It should also automatically detect what type of PC you are on.



Screenshot of Visual Studio Code website











Step 3: Create or move to a folder for LS6036






Click “Open Folder” on the loading screen
Browse files until you can find your documents - wherever you keep your university files.
Create a new folder for this python course, and open this folder.




GIF of Opening OneDrive folder











Step 4: Install the python extension





Now we need to set up Visual Studio Code to recognise and use your version of python.

Click the extensions tab
Search and install python




GIF of Making a Folder











Step 5: Write and run a python file





You’re now ready to run some Python code!

Go back to your folder
Click the “New file” button
Give your file a name ending .py (e.g. “Test.py” )
Add the following line to your file


print("Hello World")


Press the run button

And that’s it - you’re all set up!



GIF of making a python File

title: LS6036 Python Course
text:
This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: Comments
text:
Comments
One of the most important practices in programming is to use good comments.
Comments help explain what the code is doing - to another programmer, to whoever is marking your assignments, to your future self (you will forget how your own code works!).
Comments are sections of the code that are ignored by the compiler - they aren’t executed like the rest of your code. In python, you can comment by:

# Starting with a '#' (this is the best way!)
"""Wrapping text in triple quotes"""

Try the below example:

title: Data Types
text:
Data Types
In the previous examples, we’ve only been using strings. A string is a collection of characters - such as letters, numbers and punctuation.
We can also use different data types. Below are some examples of different data types and how we define them in python.

Python Data types









Data Type
Shorthand
Description
Define With
Examples




String
str
A collection of characters
Quotes “” or ’’
x = “5 jumping chimpanzees”


Integer
int
A whole number
Digit without quotes or decimal point
x = 5


Float
float
A floating point number
Digit with a decimal point, no quotes
x = 5.7


List
list
A collection of strings, integers, floats or lists
Square brackets [ ]
x = [“5 jumping chimpanzees”, 5, 5.7]



We can check what type our variable is using the function type().
Try:






Change the line x = 5.7 to the other examples in Table 1 - what do you get each time?
This will be really useful when we have errors in our code - we might think we’re using an integer when our variable is actually a string…

title: Maths
text:
We’ve looked at saving a numerical value (integer or float) as a variable. Next we can look at doing mathematics in python. Table 2 contains example code for different mathematical operations and how we write them.

Python Mathematics








Operator
Name
Example
Example code




+
Addition
2 plus 5
2 + 5


-
Subtraction
7 minus 3
7 - 3


*
Multiplication
3 times 4
3 * 4


/
Division
10 divided by 2
10 / 2


%
Modulus
Remainder from 10 divided by 3
10 % 3


**
Exponentiation
3 to the power of 4
3 ** 4


//
Floor division
10 divided by 3, rounded down to nearest integer
10 // 3



Try the below code, and then change the mathematical operator as in the above Table. Does the result that prints out match what you expect?








In python, arithmetic operations always occur in the following order:

Exponential **
Multiplication * or division (/ or // or % )
Addition + or subtraction -

Where there is two operations of the same level (eg. one * and one / ) then the order depends on which comes first.
Just like in mathematics, we can use brackets ( ) to highlight which operations should be done first.
What would be the result of the following equations in python? Calculate them manually (without python) first.

4 - 3 * 5 + 6
4 - ( 3 * 5 ) + 6
(4 - 3) * 5 + 6

4 - (3 * 5 + 6)
4 - 3.0 * 5 + 6
4. - ( 3 * 5 ) + 6
(4 + 2) / 5 + 6

4 // (3 * 5 + 6.)

Now try the above in python. You can do this using print() like in the example below. Were your predictions correct?






Note: In Python, you can mix integers and floats in the same arithmetic expression. The type of the evaluation will be a float.






Side note: Rounding errors





A float is any number with a decimal point, whereas an integer is a whole number (eg. 5.0 is a float and 5 is an integer)
In python, there’s something a little unusual about mathematical calculations with floats…
Try:






Did you get what you expected? What do you think is going on here?
Confused? This is to do with how the hardware stores numbers in binary - it isn’t a bug with the python code. You can check out more in this geeks for geeks article.

title: Format Strings
text:
We can also print our variables within a string using a format string.
This can be really useful when we want to print multiple pieces of information from our python program and need to know which is which.
A format string is similar to a string but starts with an f: f"Add string here"
And we can insert the value of one of our variables using curly brackets {}
See example below:








See if you can make a format string to print the following:
Escherichia coli is a Gram negative bacteria













Hint 1





Put the variable names inside of curly brackets {}










Show answer






species = "Escherichia coli"
gramtype = "Gram negative"

print(f"{species} is a {gramtype} bacteria")

Escherichia coli is a Gram negative bacteria

title: Format Strings
text:
See if you can make a format string to print the following:
Escherichia coli is a Gram negative bacteria













Hint 1





Put the variable names inside of curly brackets {}










Show answer

gramtype = "Gram negative"

print(f"{species} is a {gramtype} bacteria")

title: Oxygen in blood exercise
text:
A patient has the following blood oxygen readings:

Patient 1 haemoglobin measurements


Type
Measurement
Units




Haemoglobin concentration
15
g / dL blood


Haemoglobin saturation
96
%


Arterial oxygen tension
89
mmHg





Every gram of hemoglobin can maximally bind 1.34 mL of oxygen.
This mean we can calculate the maximum amount of oxygen bound to haemoglobin by multiplying the concentration of haemoglobin [Hb] (in g / dL blood) with this value 1.34 mL O_2 per g haemoglobin.
However, not all haemoglobin in the blood is bound to oxygen. We can multiply the maximum amount of oxygen bound to haemoglobin by the haemoglobin saturation to calculate the amount of oxygen bound in the blood.
\[
\text{Bound oxygen} = [Hb] \frac{\text{g Hb}}{\text{dL}} \times 1.34 \frac {\text{mL } O_2}{\text{g Hb}} \times \frac{\text{Hb saturation}}{100}
\]














Show answer






Hb_concentration = 15
Hb_saturation = 96
Max_oxygen_per_Hb = 1.34 

Bound_oxygen = Hb_concentration * Hb_saturation * Max_oxygen_per_Hb
print(Bound_oxygen)

1929.6000000000001









There is also a small amount of oxygen dissolved in the blood, not bound to haemoglobin.
We can calculate this by multiplying the arterial oxygen tension (in mmHg) and the solubility coefficient of oxygen.
The solubility coefficient of oxygen is \(0.0031 \text{mL} \frac{\frac{O_2}{\text{dL blood}}}{\text{mmHg}}\).
\[
\text{Dissolved oxygen} = \text{arterial oxygen tension mmHg} \times 0.0031 \text{mL} \frac{\frac{O_2}{\text{dL blood}}}{\text{mmHg}}
\]














Show answer






arterial_tension = 89
solubility_coefficient = 0.0031

Dissolved_oxygen = arterial_tension * solubility_coefficient
print(Dissolved_oxygen)

0.2759









Now to calculate the total oxygen, all you need to do is combine the two and add them together!






Show answer






Hb_concentration = 15
Hb_saturation = 96
Max_oxygen_per_Hb = 1.34 

Bound_oxygen = Hb_concentration * Hb_saturation * Max_oxygen_per_Hb
print(Bound_oxygen)

arterial_tension = 89
solubility_coefficient = 0.0031

Dissolved_oxygen = arterial_tension * solubility_coefficient
print(Dissolved_oxygen)

Total_oxygen = Bound_oxygen + Dissolved_oxygen 
print(Total_oxygen)

1929.6000000000001
0.2759
1929.8759000000002





Now if we have a second patient with different readings - how quickly can you calculate the total blood oxygen?

Patient 2 haemoglobin measurements


Type
Measurement
Units




Haemoglobin concentration
12
g / dL blood


Haemoglobin saturation
94
%


Arterial oxygen tension
76
mmHg

text:
Every gram of hemoglobin can maximally bind 1.34 mL of oxygen.
This mean we can calculate the maximum amount of oxygen bound to haemoglobin by multiplying the concentration of haemoglobin [Hb] (in g / dL blood) with this value 1.34 mL O_2 per g haemoglobin.
However, not all haemoglobin in the blood is bound to oxygen. We can multiply the maximum amount of oxygen bound to haemoglobin by the haemoglobin saturation to calculate the amount of oxygen bound in the blood.
\[
\text{Bound oxygen} = [Hb] \frac{\text{g Hb}}{\text{dL}} \times 1.34 \frac {\text{mL } O_2}{\text{g Hb}} \times \frac{\text{Hb saturation}}{100}
\]

There is also a small amount of oxygen dissolved in the blood, not bound to haemoglobin.
We can calculate this by multiplying the arterial oxygen tension (in mmHg) and the solubility coefficient of oxygen.
The solubility coefficient of oxygen is \(0.0031 \text{mL} \frac{\frac{O_2}{\text{dL blood}}}{\text{mmHg}}\).
\[
\text{Dissolved oxygen} = \text{arterial oxygen tension mmHg} \times 0.0031 \text{mL} \frac{\frac{O_2}{\text{dL blood}}}{\text{mmHg}}
\]














Show answer






arterial_tension = 89

Dissolved_oxygen = arterial_tension * solubility_coefficient
print(Dissolved_oxygen)

0.2759

Now to calculate the total oxygen, all you need to do is combine the two and add them together!

arterial_tension = 89

Total_oxygen = Bound_oxygen + Dissolved_oxygen 
print(Total_oxygen)

0.2759

Now if we have a second patient with different readings - how quickly can you calculate the total blood oxygen?

Patient 2 haemoglobin measurements

Arterial oxygen tension

mmHg

title: User input
text:
Python allows for user input, using the function input().
This means we can write a program which asks the user (whoever is running the program) to input some data which we will then use in our code.
Like with print(), anything we put inside the brackets () will be printed as a message in the output.
However, the code will then stop running until the user has entered some data and pressed the enter key on their keyboard.
The data the user enters is then returned from the input function. This means we can save it in a variable.
Try the below example:

# Ask for user's name 
user_name = input("What is your name? ")
print("Your name is", user_name)

You type in your input in the output region:

Visual Studio CodeGoogle Colab





VSCode User Input Screencast







Colab User Input Screencast







The returned result of the input() function will always be a string…
Try the below example - it should give you an error!

# Calculate users age in 10 years
user_age = input("What is your age? ")
future_age = user_age + 10
print("In ten years you will be ", future_age)

You should get the error:



---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In[2], line 1
----> 1 future_age = user_age + 10

TypeError: can only concatenate str (not "int") to str



This is because the age the user types in - although the user probably used digits, such as 32, - is read into python by the input() function as a string.
To change a string to a numerical value, so that we can do things like addition, we need to use the int() or float() functions.
Examples of different functions to use data types is found below:

# Change from a string to an integer using str()
my_string = "10"
my_int = int(my_string)
print (my_int, "is of type", type ( my_int ))

# Change from a string to a floating point number using float()
my_string = "10.5"
my_float = float(my_string)
print (my_float, "is of type", type ( my_float ))

# Change from an integer to a string using str()
my_int = 10
my_string = str(my_int)
print (my_string, "is of type", type ( my_string ))




Write a python program which:

Asks the user which year they were born
Calculates how old they will be in the year 3000
Prints this information back to the user







Show answer






# Get user birth year using input()
user_birth_year = input("What year were you born?")

# Convert birth year to integer
user_birth_year = int(user_birth_year)

# Calculate age in the Year 3000
user_year_3000_age = 3000 - user_birth_year 

# Print result
print("In the year 3000 you will be: ", user_year_3000_age)

text:

# Calculate users age in 10 years
user_age = input("What is your age? ")

----> 1 future_age = user_age + 10

This is because the age the user types in - although the user probably used digits, such as 32, - is read into python by the input() function as a string.
To change a string to a numerical value, so that we can do things like addition, we need to use the int() or float() functions.

title: User input
text:
Write a python program which:

Asks the user which year they were born
Calculates how old they will be in the year 3000
Prints this information back to the user







Show answer






# Get user birth year using input()
user_birth_year = input("What year were you born?")

# Convert birth year to integer
user_birth_year = int(user_birth_year)

# Calculate age in the Year 3000
user_year_3000_age = 3000 - user_birth_year 

# Print result
print("In the year 3000 you will be: ", user_year_3000_age)

title: If and else
text:
Sometimes we may want our code to act differently in different situations. For example, if we write a program to translate an mRNA sequence to an amino acid chain, we want the program to only start at the start codon and stop once we reach the stop codon.
To do this we can use python keywords if and else. This follows the following struture:

if {condition} :
indented code for if condition is True
else:
indented code for if condition is False
un-indented rest of code

An indent is either 4 spaces "    " or a tab at the start of a line. This signals that we want this code to be part of the if/else statement.






Automatic indenting





When you write in Visual Studio Code or in Google Colab, it should automatically add the indentation for you as you write!
This should happen after you’ve written your if statement ending with : and then press enter.
To exit the indentation, you need to press backspace. You’ll need to do this when you want to add your else statement, or any code you don’t want in your if/else.

Visual Studio CodeGoogle Colab





VSCode indentation screencase







Colab indentation Screencast








Try the below example. This code uses True which is a boolean data type.






We can also visualise this with a flow chart:



Flowchart of if statement




Try: the above if statement, but changing…

still_alive = true
still_alive = TRUE
still_alive = False
still_alive = "False"
still_alive = 0
still_alive = 1
still_alive = 0.1

Do you understand the above? Are there any that surprised you?
Boolean True and False are their own data type (‘bool’), like strings or integers…

print ( type (True) )

<class 'bool'>

title: If and else conditions
text:
See below table for a list of conditions that you can use with an if statement.
The condition always goes between if and : and is evaluated to be True or False.

If else conditions








Condition
Example
When True
When False




Integers and floats
7, 2.3, 0
Any value except 0 or 0.0
0 or 0.0


String
"hello"
At least one character in string h
Empty string ""


Greater than > or Less than <
5 > 10
If correct (5 is greater than 10)
If incorrect (5 is not greater than 10)


Greater than or equal to >= or Less than or equal to <=
3 <= 3
If correct (3 is less than or equal to 3)
If incorrect (3 is less than or equal to 3)


Is equal to ==
"apple" == "banana"
If two items are exactly the same
If two items are different


Is not equal to !=
"apple" != "banana"
If two items are different
If two items are exactly the same


in
"p" in apple
If item is in string, list or dictionary
If item is not in string, list or dictionary


not in
"p" not in apple
If item is not in string, list or dictionary
If item is in string, list or dictionary

title: Fix the errors activity
text:
Fix the errors activity
Below are a set of if statements - they all have errors in. Can you fix them?

Fix the error 1:Fix the error 2:Fix the error 3:



my_value = 0.01 
if my_value
  print(my_value, "is not 0")
else: 
  print(my_value, "is 0")


  Cell In[7], line 2
    if my_value
               ^
SyntaxError: expected ':'










Show answer






my_value = 0.01 
if my_value: # : was missing at the end of if statement
  print(my_value, "is not 0")
else: 
  print(my_value, "is 0")

0.01 is not 0








user_age = 14
age_restriction = 18

if user_age < age_restriction:
print("You are too young")
else: 
print("You are old enough")


  Cell In[9], line 5
    print("You are too young")
    ^
IndentationError: expected an indented block after 'if' statement on line 4










Show answer






user_age = 14
age_restriction = 18

if user_age < age_restriction:
    print("You are too young") # indentation was missing (four spaces at start of line)
else: 
    print("You are old enough") # indentation was missing (four spaces at start of line)

You are too young








# Check if species belongs to genus
target_genus = "Trypanosoma"
my_species = "Trypanosoma brucei"

if Target_genus in my_species:
  print(f"{my_species} is part of {target_genus}")
else: 
  print(f"{my_species} is not part of {target_genus}")


---------------------------------------------------------------------------
NameError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In[11], line 5
      2 target_genus = "Trypanosoma"
      3 my_species = "Trypanosoma brucei"
----> 5 if Target_genus in my_species:
      6   print(f"{my_species} is part of {target_genus}")
      7 else: 

NameError: name 'Target_genus' is not defined









Show answer






# Check if species belongs to genus
target_genus = "Trypanosoma"
my_species = "Trypanosoma brucei"

# python is case sensenitive 
# if your variable is target_genus (with no capital letters) then you always need to refer to is as target_genus. 
if target_genus in my_species:
  print(f"{my_species} is part of {target_genus}")
else: 
  print(f"{my_species} is not part of {target_genus}")

Trypanosoma brucei is part of Trypanosoma

title: If and else fix the errors
text:
Below are a list of if statements - they all have errors in. Can you fix them?
Fix the error 1:

my_value = 0.01 
if my_value
  print(my_value, "is not 0")
else: 
  print(my_value, "is 0")


  Cell In[7], line 2
    if my_value
               ^
SyntaxError: expected ':'










Show answer






my_value = 0.01 
if my_value: # : was missing at the end of if statement
  print(my_value, "is not 0")
else: 
  print(my_value, "is 0")

0.01 is not 0





Fix the error 2:

user_age = 14
age_restriction = 18

if user_age < age_restriction:
print("You are too young")
else: 
print("You are old enough")


  Cell In[9], line 5
    print("You are too young")
    ^
IndentationError: expected an indented block after 'if' statement on line 4










Show answer






user_age = 14
age_restriction = 18

if user_age < age_restriction:
    print("You are too young") # indentation was missing (four spaces at start of line)
else: 
    print("You are old enough") # indentation was missing (four spaces at start of line)

You are too young





Fix the error 3:

day_of_travel = "day 10" 
month_of_travel = "06"
year_of_travel = "2029"

if day_of_travel.isdigit:
  day_of_travel = int(day_of_travel)
else: 
  print("Please change day_of_travel to a numerical value")


---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In[11], line 6
      3 year_of_travel = "2029"
      5 if day_of_travel.isdigit:
----> 6   day_of_travel = int(day_of_travel)
      7 else: 
      8   print("Please change day_of_travel to a numerical value")

ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'day 10'



This last one is a bit different - if the if statement was working correctly, would we get that error?






Show answer






day_of_travel = "day 10" 
month_of_travel = "06"
year_of_travel = "2029"

if day_of_travel.isdigit(): # brackets () were missing after .isdigit 
  # the brackets () are needed to run the function (to see if day_of_travel is made of only digits)
  # without this, we would get true every time... 
  day_of_travel = int(day_of_travel)
else: 
  print("Please change day_of_travel to a numerical value")

Please change day_of_travel to a numerical value
crumbs: If and else fix the errors

title: If, elif and else
text:
What do we do if we have three conditions? In the below example, there are two if statements but this doesn’t work quite how we want it to.

dog_or_cat_person = "dog"
if dog_or_cat_person == "dog": 
  print("You are a dog person")
if dog_or_cat_person == "cat": 
  print("You are a cat person")
else: 
  print("You are not a dog or a cat person")

You are a dog person
You are not a dog or a cat person


In the above example, two of our conditions printed out. Even though the user was a dog person, the line “You are not a dog or a cat person” printed out as well.
This is because the second time we have an if, python has assumed this is unrelated to the first if. The else will execute if the second if only is False.
The below flow chart explains what has happened:



If if flowchart




elif, short for else if, can be used instead so that many different conditions can be tried in sequence.

dog_or_cat_person = "dog"

# first if statement
if dog_or_cat_person == "dog": 
  print("You are a dog person")
  
# elif - for if the first if statement is False and this elif is True
elif dog_or_cat_person == "cat": 
  print("You are a cat person")
  
# else - for if both if and elif are false
else: 
  print("You are not a dog or a cat person")

You are a dog person


This then ties together both conditions:



If elif else flowchart


You can add as many elif statements as you need.
See the below example with two elif statements:

dog_or_cat_or_bird_person = "bird"

# first if statement
if dog_or_cat_or_bird_person == "dog": 
  print("You are a dog person")
  
# elif - for if the first if statement is False and this elif is True
elif dog_or_cat_or_bird_person == "cat": 
  print("You are a cat person")
  
# elif - for if the previous if and elif statements are False and this elif is True
elif dog_or_cat_or_bird_person == "bird": 
  print("You are a bird person")
  
# else - for if both if and elif are false
else: 
  print("You are not a dog or a cat person")

You are a bird person


We can also visualise this with a flow chart.



Flow chart of if elif elif else example

title: If and else
text:
Try: the above if statement, but changing…

still_alive = true
still_alive = TRUE
still_alive = False
still_alive = "False"
still_alive = 0
still_alive = 1
still_alive = 0.1

Do you understand the above? Are there any that surprised you?
Boolean True and False are their own data type (‘bool’), like strings or integers…

print ( type (True) )

<class 'bool'>

title: Museum discount activity
text:
Museum discount activity
Build this program one step at a time, checking part 1 works before moving onto part 2…
A museum needs you to write a program to decide if a visitor is entitled to a reduction in the price of the ticket. The program should start by asking what the age of the visitor is.
Your program should:

Ask the user to input their age
print ‘Reduced’ if the visitor is under 26 years old
Also print ‘Reduced’ if the visitor is over 60 years old
print ‘Full price’ if the visitor is not eligible for a discount







Show hint





The function input() will always give you a string. Make sure you convert this to an integer or a float before doing your if statements.
